0.83.text:
It is day two of Vlognukkah,
where I'm uploading

3.02.text:
daily videos for the
eight days of Hanukkah.

6.08.text:
And I thought today I
would just do a unscripted

9.85.text: chat about my relationship with religion.

13.06.text:
Completely by coincidence,
'cause I do wear

14.44.text: this hoodie all of the time.

15.60.text: It is my Zion Canyon Utah hoodie,

19.26.text:
which is obviously like
the home to Mormons.

24.79.text: I wish I was sitting down.

25.75.text:
Why did I choose to stand
up to talk about this?

27.43.text: I just wanna be like chill.

28.97.text:
This isn't going to really
be a debate video about

31.56.text:
whether or not God exists
or this is the right way

35.02.text:
to do things, this is the
wrong way to do things,

39.26.text:
I'm just going to talk
about my personal experience

43.02.text:
with religion and how I
kind of see the world.

47.07.text: And I would just love to hear like

48.86.text:
your thoughts and
opinions in the comments.

51.57.text: In kind of just, I'm interested.

54.97.text: As you would have gathered by now

56.34.text: by the whole Hanukkah thing, I'm Jewish.

58.11.text:
Being Jewish is passed
down through the mother,

59.60.text: so my mum is Jewish but my dad is not.

61.79.text:
Being Jewish for me has
always been a really

64.22.text:
significant and important
part of my identity,

67.04.text: but I have never believed in a god.

69.27.text: I've been raised as a secular Jew,

71.48.text: which to me means that it's part of

74.33.text: my culture and it's part of my heritage.

76.83.text:
And for me, it's about
family and tradition.

80.13.text: I went Ha-da, which is like Sunday school,

83.97.text:
I didn't have a bat mitzvah,
but that was because I couldn't

87.60.text:
be bothered and my mum was
kinda pretty chill about it.

90.04.text: I just said, "I don't wanna do one,"

93.27.text: I learnt how to read Hebrew,

94.61.text: even though I can't understand it.

96.75.text: I can read some of the letters.

98.33.text: And a lot of the songs and prayers,

100.72.text: I just kind of have memorised,

102.45.text:
even though I don't really
know what they mean.

104.14.text: I think it means even more to me

105.42.text: because of my German Jewish identity.

107.63.text:
So I'm like a quarter
German, so I'm barely German.

110.88.text:
But my great-grandmother
and my great-grandfather

114.54.text: both grew up and lived in Germany.

117.34.text:
I know that my great-grandmother
came to England

119.82.text: before the Nazis rose to power and so she

123.49.text: kind of just stayed in England whilst

125.70.text:
that was all happening
and didn't go back home.

128.00.text:
And then because she
was from east Germany,

129.57.text:
she couldn't go back home until
the Berlin Wall fell down.

132.14.text:
And then my great-granddad,
I'm not entirely sure,

134.61.text:
but I think it was maybe
during the second world war

136.86.text: or something, he managed to escape.

138.27.text: And my great grandparents met in England.

140.84.text: And my great-grandmother is still alive.

142.02.text:
She's a 102 years old
on the 31st of December.

146.13.text:
By the way, the light is
gonna change 'cause there's

147.63.text:
a window right here and
the sun is just setting.

149.74.text:
So a lot of my Jewish identity
is also very much connected

153.14.text:
to Germany and the Holocaust
and my great grandparents.

157.38.text: But like I said, I don't believe in God.

159.96.text:
My dad is from a kinda
Christian family, I guess.

161.98.text:
Like his dad or like
grandparents and uncles,

165.19.text:
there's a lot of priests,
I think, in his family.

169.50.text: I'm pretty sure his family is Protestant,

170.77.text:
but I was never really
raised Christian at all

174.18.text: because I was mostly raised Jewish.

176.06.text:
But then we did like Christmas
and Easter because they're

179.60.text:
just like such a part of
kinda British culture as well.

182.92.text: But I will say, I was heavily influenced

185.63.text: by my dad in terms of my Atheism

187.97.text: and just growing up being really adamant

190.65.text: that there was no such thing as God.

192.72.text:
I very much grew up in a
Liberal, Atheist, Jewish bubble.

196.67.text:
Didn't really know any religious
people, never met anyone

200.18.text:
that identified as a
Christian until I was 17.

204.21.text: And I'm ashamed to say it now, but when I

206.44.text: was a teenager, I genuinely believed that

209.48.text: people who believed in God were stupid,

211.66.text:
people that believed in God
were less intelligent than me,

214.67.text:
and I was better than them
because I knew the truth

219.00.text:
and the truth was that
there's no such thing as God.

220.71.text:
And that didn't change at all
until I went to university.

224.24.text:
So, in my first year at
uni, I lived in halls,

226.62.text:
and you're just put into
a big block of flats

229.03.text: with loads of other first year students,

231.13.text: and a large portion of the people that

234.24.text: I lived with in my halls were Christians.

236.59.text:
And then when we moved out
into houses in second year,

238.90.text: I lived with other Christian women.

241.41.text:
And these women are some of my
best friends and they kind of

244.57.text:
just changed the whole way
I think about religion.

248.23.text:
Basically what happened
was, I met these women

250.32.text:
and I suddenly discovered
that religious people

254.11.text:
aren't stupid and actually
they're really intelligent

256.52.text:
and everyone has their
own reasons and stories

259.95.text: behind why they may believe in a god

263.66.text:
or a certain religious
text or whatever it is.

266.59.text:
And we had loads of
conversations about it.

269.47.text:
I would ask them loads of
questions about their faith

273.11.text:
and they would ask me questions
about my faith in terms of

277.10.text:
Judaism, but also then my lack
of in terms of the Atheism.

280.78.text: We had these really caring and loving

283.09.text:
and curious conversations about
it that were non-judgemental

288.91.text:
and just really fascinating
and I learnt so much.

293.14.text:
I also went to loads of
Christian events at university,

295.83.text:
but a big part of that was
probably the free food.

299.00.text:
You're a student, you gotta
get free food wherever you can.

302.65.text:
So what was interesting
for me actually was that

304.96.text:
my dad was going through
a similar transformation

308.12.text:
in terms of how he viewed
religion at the same time

311.19.text:
as me but completely
separately, like I'd moved out.

314.56.text:
And my dad was like
such a huge influence in

317.63.text:
my life in terms of how
I felt about religion,

321.17.text:
in terms of the negative
feelings I had towards it.

323.63.text: And then me and him like, just both

325.32.text: separately changed at the same time.

327.54.text:
My parents had a couple
people from the Democratic

329.79.text:
Republic of Congo staying
with us in Manchester

333.17.text: because of reasons that I won't go into.

335.17.text:
But my dad would drive
them to church every Sunday

337.92.text:
'cause they were Christians and
they wanted to go to church.

339.93.text:
So my dad started making friends
at church and it gradually

342.44.text:
kinda grew on him and he
was starting to enjoy it.

344.36.text: And then he would sometimes go on his own.

346.61.text:
It was then really interesting
coming back home and me

348.86.text:
and my dad both having these
conversations about religion

352.20.text:
that were so different to the
conversations that we would

354.78.text:
be having about religion
like six months before that.

358.10.text: with the idea that God exists.

359.47.text: Like to me, he just doesn't exist.

361.06.text: I don't feel his presence at all.

363.92.text: And actually, since then, I have gone

365.99.text:
to church on Christmas
morning with my dad.

368.64.text: Mostly out of like a support for him

370.97.text:
and wanting to know a
bit more about his life,

374.41.text: since I've moved out and don't really

376.37.text: get to see him on a day to day basis.

378.14.text:
But also because there's
loads of cute babies

380.29.text: at church and so that's really great.

382.89.text: So here's one of the things that I

384.13.text: still find really tricky about religion.

386.67.text:
I'm definitely a lot less
judgemental of religious people.

389.74.text:
I still have to check with
myself every time it comes up,

392.11.text:
but definitely better,
definitely working on it.

394.72.text:
The thing that I still
find really difficult

398.62.text:
is organised religion, is
the history around religion,

404.13.text:
and the things that people
do in the name of God.

410.53.text:
Just historically, all of
the wars that have been

412.36.text: started over religion, all of the violence

415.13.text:
and all of the hatred
and all of the anger.

418.10.text:
There's something in me that
thinks that there's something

420.66.text:
fundamentally wrong with
religion, like all religion,

425.50.text:
if people can draw such
hateful conclusions from them

428.80.text:
and start wars and be
violent in the name of God.

432.63.text:
And there are wonderful
religious people that

434.37.text: don't believe in any of that stuff at all

436.99.text:
and are lovely and are
kind and are charitable

439.69.text:
and are accepting and
all of those good things.

442.35.text: I find it really hard to understand.

444.22.text:
I'm trying to understand,
but I find it really hard

447.19.text:
to understand how there
can be one group who are

451.47.text: really violent and really hateful and then

455.10.text:
a really accepting and
loving and kind group

459.80.text:
who both say that they
are of the same religion.

464.90.text:
And one group is saying,
"No, that's not Christian."

473.18.text:
I can totally respect
someone's individual faith,

476.21.text:
but then as soon as I zoom
out and as soon as I start

478.96.text: to see just religion and religious groups

483.16.text:
and the organised religion and
also just the general themes

488.29.text: and the patterns and everything that

492.58.text:
kind of at its core has
been caused by religion,

496.33.text:
all the bad things, I
just can't ignore that.

501.08.text:
So how I generally identify
now is, one, as Jewish,

504.10.text: as an Atheist but also as Agnostic.

507.86.text: So, an Agnostic Atheist, I think.

510.61.text:
There's gonna be loads of
you who are like philosophy

512.45.text:
or theology students who
are gonna tell me that

515.36.text:
the meanings that I've put
on these words is wrong.

518.09.text:
But this is how I understand
their meaning, so bear with me.

520.61.text:
So Atheism is the belief
that there's no God.

523.12.text: Being Agnostic means you don't know.

525.30.text:
The reason why I say that
I'm an Agnostic Atheist

528.67.text:
is because the Agnostic
bit is about knowledge

531.37.text: and the Atheist bit is about belief.

535.19.text: I don't know if God exists.

538.01.text: I have no idea, couldn't tell you.

540.34.text: I've got no evidence for his existence

542.54.text:
and I've got no evidence
for him not existing.

545.12.text:
But even though I don't
know if there is a God,

548.44.text: I don't believe that there is.

550.12.text: Like, I feel like exhausted from just

551.97.text: talking about it because I'm like, oh.

556.57.text:
Please give this video a
thumbs up if you enjoyed it

558.51.text: and I would genuinely really love to hear

561.38.text:
your thoughts in the
comments on all of this.

563.76.text: Please don't argue with each other.

565.45.text: Please don't say mean things, just be open

568.67.text:
and kind and have a
discussion, have a debate.

570.81.text: Happy Hanukkah and I'll see you tomorrow.
